title: HTML Canvas Circles

metadata.description: Learn about HTML Canvas Circles with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
The arc() Method
The
arc()
method is used to define a circle.
The
arc()
method has the following parameters:
Parameter
Description
x
Required. The x-coordinate of the arc's center
y
Required. The y-coordinate of the arc's center
radius
Required. The radius of the arc
startAngle
Required. The angle where the arc starts in radians
endAngle
Required. The angle where the arc ends in radians
counterclockwise
Optional. A boolean value. If set to true, it draws the arc 
    counter-clockwise between the start and end angles. The default is false 
    (clockwise)
Draw a Full Circle
We can create a full circle with the
arc()
method by defining the startAngle as 0 and the endAngle 
as 2 * PI:
To draw a circle on the canvas, use the following methods:
beginPath()
- Begin a path
arc()
- Define a circle
stroke()
- Draw it
Example
Your browser does not support the HTML5 canvas tag.
<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");
ctx.beginPath();
ctx.arc(95, 50, 40, 0, 2 * Math.PI);
ctx.stroke();
</script>

Draw a Full Circle with Colors
Add a fill-color and a stroke-color to the circle:
Example
Your browser does not support the HTML5 canvas tag.
<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");
ctx.beginPath();
ctx.arc(95, 50, 40, 0, 2 * Math.PI);
ctx.fillStyle 
  = "red";
ctx.fill();
ctx.lineWidth = 4;
ctx.strokeStyle = "blue";
ctx.stroke();
</script>

Draw a Half Circle
Here we change the endAngle to PI (not 2 * PI):
Example
Your browser does not support the HTML5 canvas tag.
<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");
ctx.beginPath();
ctx.arc(95, 50, 40, 0, Math.PI);
ctx.fillStyle 
  = "red";
ctx.fill();
ctx.stroke();
</script>

More About the Angles of an Arc
The following image shows some of the angles in an arc:
Center: arc(
100, 75
, 50, 0 * Math.PI, 1.5 * Math.PI)
Start angle: arc(100, 75, 50,
0
, 1.5 * Math.PI)
End angle: arc(100, 75, 50, 0 * Math.PI,
1.5 * Math.PI
)
Example
Here we want to draw an arc from start-angle 0 to end-angle 0.5 * PI:
Your browser does not support the HTML5 canvas tag.
<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");
ctx.beginPath();
ctx.arc(95, 50, 40, 0, 0.5 * Math.PI);
ctx.stroke();
</script>

Example
Here we do the same, but with the counterclockwise parameter set to true (it 
then draws the arc counter-clockwise between the start and end angle):
Your browser does not support the HTML5 canvas tag.
<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");
ctx.beginPath();
ctx.arc(95, 50, 40, 0, 0.5 * Math.PI, true);
ctx.stroke();
</script>

See Also:
' Full Canvas Reference

★
+1

summary: This tutorial covers HTML Canvas Circles concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use HTML Canvas Circles effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of HTML Canvas Circles and how to apply it in your projects.
